front.title: HyperText Markup Language Request For Comments Format

abstract.t: This document defines the HTML format that will be rendered from the canonical XML format for an RFC. The HTML output will include a default CSS to enable page layout.

section.title: Background
section.t: As described in , the RFC Series is changing. One of those changes includes the RFC Editor publishing a non-canonical HTML version of RFCs.

This memo describes the HTML format that will be used as one of the publication formats for the RFC Series. It defines a strict subset of HTML appropriate for RFC Series documents. The visual layout of the document will be defined through a cascading style sheet (CSS) . The CSS will be included in the HTML file and will be described in a separate document.

section.title: Requirements for the HTML Format
section.t: This section lists the design requirements used to create the HTML format described in this document.
The HTML has to render correctly on the following:

list.t: the latest released versions of Chrome, Firefox, and Internet Explorer running on Windows 8 in November 2013
the latest released versions of Chrome, Firefox, and Safari running on Mac OS X 10.9 in November 2013
the latest released versions of Chrome and Safari running on iOS 7 in November 2013
the latest released versions of Chrome and Firefox running on Ubuntu 13.10 in November 2013
the latest released versions of Chrome and Firefox running on Android 4.1 in November 2013

section.t: These requirements are expected to change in the future to reflect the expectation that HTML rendering will be required for current versions of browsers and platforms, while ideally continuing to render correctly on earlier versions. The HTML documents may be re-rendered from the canonical XML format in the future to ensure the ongoing readability of the documents.

The HTML document will publish with a default, internal set of CSS formatting. This will allow for a mostly-consistent display of RFCs across browsers. It will also allow for the HTML file to be moved over different transports (such as e-mail) and have the result look the same.
The HTML must display adequately in at least one text-based browser. Any use of JavaScript in the HTML document must not negatively impact the ability to read the document.

The HTML document must allow easy local override of the default CSS formatting. This will allow users who have a different visual style that they prefer to make RFCs display with that style without having to alter the contents of the HTML document. This might also be valuable for allowing people with specific accessibility needs to use a customized CSS.
HTML tags in documents will rarely have attributes whose only purpose is to affect the rendered styling, and those will only be used if it would not make sense to specify that styling in CSS.

Both user-defined and autogenerated anchors must be supported and linkable, with user-defined anchors appearing in an "id" attribute. Autogenerated anchors will be generated for every heading, paragraph, and so on, not just those that do not have user-defined anchors. User-defined anchors may and autogenerated anchors will appear next to paragraphs, figures, tables, blockquotes, and section titles.
The HTML must make it easy to separate chunks into separate files. This will make creating EPUB documents easier in the future.
All section, subsections, figures, and paragraphs should have stable numbered link anchors. Additionally, anchors expressed in the source XML should be exposed as anchors in the HTML as well.
The abstract must be marked up or tagged in a way that search engines will extract it as a summary.
Normative information must be easily accessible to the following consumers:

list.t: People with impaired vision, including those that use large fonts and those that use screen readers
People with difficulty distinguishing between colors
People who use devices with small screens, such as cell phones

section.t: Specific instances where goals for accessibility are important in the design choices of the format have been called out in the text.

NOTE: designing for these consumers does not preclude the use of features they cannot use, but does require that key semantic data is not lost when read using the tools and settings that are required by a given constituency.

section.title: HTML Format
section.t: The format specified here is a subset of HTML, deemed to be widely-implemented by common browsers at the time that this specification was created, likely to continue to be widely-implemented in the future, and unlikely to cause security issues.

section.title: Syntax
section.t: The processor emitting HTML from the XML source will follow these rules:

list.t: The HTML source is encoded as UTF-8, as specified in RFC3629. Note that RFC3629 forbids "surrogate" code points in the range U+D800 to U+DFFF.
Single quotes (U+0027 APOSTROPHE: ') are used to quote attribute values. No unquoted attribute values will be used.
Each logical line is terminated solely with a \n (U+000A: LINE FEED), otherwise known as "Unix-style" line endings.

Other than \n (U+000A: LINE FEED), code points less than " " (U+0020: SPACE) (otherwise known as "control characters") are not used. Any character references that would generate these code points (e.g., 	) may not be used. NOTE: this rule explicitly forbids \t (U+0009: CHARACTER TABULATION), \f (U+000C: FORM FEED), and \r (U+000D: CARRIAGE RETURN) from appearing in the source.

Each text-containing element such as headings (

-

), paragraphs (

), or list items (

  • ), is serialized as a single line without wrapping.

The contents of <pre> elements will not be modified by processing tools. The following rules apply to all elements except for <pre>: HTML is indented using spaces (not tabs).Each child element is indented two spaces more than its parent element, unless the child element is mixed with non-whitespace-only text children of the same parent element.

section.t: NOTE: none of these rules affect the rendered output of the HTML, but are intended to increase the chance that multiple tools that process the format will generate identical syntax. In turn, this will make difference tools that operate on the HTML source easier to write.

section.title: HTML5
section.t: The HTML comprising the document needs to be valid according to the latest version of the HTML specification at the time of publishing, starting with the version commonly known as HTML5. Although the HTML specification mandates several of syntax and structure rules in this document, they are called out here for emphasis.

section.title: DOCTYPE
section.t: The DOCTYPE of the document is "html", which declares that the document is compliant with HTML5. The document will start with exactly this string:

section.title: Root Element
section.t: The root element of the document is <html>. This element includes a lang attribute, whose value is a RFC5646 language tag describing the natural language of the document. The language of the RFC Series is English and so the language tag to be included is 'en'.

section.title: Charset Declaration
section.t: In order to be correctly processed by browsers that load the HTML using a mechanism that does not provide a valid MIME content-type or charset, the HTML <head> element contains a <meta> element, with charset attribute with value 'utf-8'. This will look like:

section.title: Style
section.t: The <head> contains an embedded CSS stylesheet in a <style> element. The styles in the stylesheet are to be set consistently between documents by the RFC Editor, according to the best practices of the day.

To ensure consistent formatting, individual style attributes are not used in the main portion of the document source except in highly exceptional circumstances; each use of such attributes will be individually justified.

Different readers of a specification will desire different formatting when reading the HTML versions of RFCs. To facilitate this, the <head> includes a <style> tag for the formatting from the RFC Editor and a <link> to a stylesheet in the same directory as the HTML file, named "rfc-local.css". Any formatting in the linked stylesheet will override the formatting in the included stylesheet.
For example:

figure.artwork: <head> <style type='text/css'> <! -- /* RFC-editor styles */ --> </style> <link rel='stylesheet' type='text/css' href='local.css' /> </head>

section.title: Emphasis
section.t: Words or phrases may be emphasized using the <em> element, usually rendered as italics. Strong emphasis may be denoted with the <strong> element, which is usually rendered as boldface. Underlining will not be used except for links, to avoid visual confusion. Text formatting emphasis indicated in the XML will be rendered in the HTML as HTML markup.

section.title: Comments
section.t: Comments in the canonical XML, if any, will not be copied into the HTML.

section.title: Sections
section.t: Each section of the document is formatted as a <div> tag, with a class attribute with value 'section'. A document-unique id attribute is assigned to each section <div>. Every block item, including section, that can have a user-generated anchor will have than anchor expressed in the item's non-div tag as an id attribute.
NOTE: HTML5 requires id attributes to be unique across an entire document.

Each section <div> will contain a header tag (<h2>-<h6>) of the appropriate depth, with top-level sections getting an <h2> tag, and each nested section getting the next higher header level. If more than five levels of headers are required, <h6> is used for each deeper-nested section.i In addition, section headings in HTML will have two <a> tags: around the section number (with a relative link to the <div>), and optionally around the section title text (with a relative link to the <h#>, if there is an id attribute there)

The text in each header tag begins with the section number. Section numbers begin at "1.", and will increment by one for each successive section at the same level. Subsections are numbered by appending the subsection number to the parent section number.

The section number is wrapped in an <a> element whose href attribute points to the corresponding section <div> with a local relative reference to the auto-generated id for the section. If the section also has a user-generated anchor, the section title is wrapped in an <a> element whose href attribute points to the corresponding section <div> with that id. This <a> element has the CSS class self-ref.

section.title: Appendices
section.t: Appendices are special cases of top-level sections. Each appendix of the document is formatted as a <div> tag, with a class attribute with value 'appendix'. The appendix is wrapped with <div> tags using the same rules as for sections. Appendices are identified to the reader with Latin capital letters A-Z, in order. A document should not have more than 26 appendices, but if required, appendices "AA.", "AB.", etc. follow Appendix Z.
Inside the appendix, subsections are formatted per Sections, numbered sequentially. For example, the first subsection of "Appendix A." is "Appendix A.1.".

section.title: Lists
section.t: Lists may be used inside a section or paragraph, and may nest in other lists as needed. Unordered lists (<ul>), ordered lists (<ol>), and definition lists (<dl>) may all appear.

section.title: References
section.t: Reference format will follow the guidance in the RFC Style Guide .

section.title: More Elaborate Information
section.t: This section describes how several specific types of information that occur regularly in documents for the RFC Series should be formatted.

section.title: Formatting the Table of Contents
section.t: The table of contents for the document appears in a <div> element, which precedes any of the sections of proper document content. The <div> element has an id attribute with value 'toc'. The <div> element contains an <h2> element containing the string Table of Contents, followed by nested <ul> and <li> elements describing the structure of the document, with links to each of the sections mentioned. For example:
NOTE: the Table of Contents is not meta-data for the document. The sections themselves contain all of the data that is required.

section.title: SVG
section.t: SVG can be included directly in the HTML source, surrounded by a <figure> element and succeeded by a <figcaption> element. The root <svg> element contains a <title> or <desc> element that fully describes the diagram for accessibility to screen readers; this is similar to the alt; attribute on images. See "SVG Drawings for RFCs: SVG 1.2 RFC" for details on the appropriate SVG profile for use in RFCs .

section.title: Inline Code
section.t: Use the <code> element to set aside literal references to code or protocol elements in the middle of a paragraph. If desired, the language of the code or protocol can be declared using a class attribute starting with language-. For example:
Use the <;code>; element

section.title: Blocks of Code
section.t: Larger sections of code or protocol can be included using a <pre> element with a class attribute of code. If desired, the language of the code or protocol can be declared using a further class value starting with 'language-' (multiple class values are separated by spaces in HTML). section.title: Document Metadata
section.t: The XML representation of the RFC contains all of the document metadata; the HTML representation contains only some of that metadata .

Typically, the class and id attributes of various tags can be used to query the document using CSS-style selectors. The metadata scheme is designed such that the element name is not required in order to select a given piece of data. Instead, any element that can contain text can be used for a given class or id to be selected. The value of the data contained by the selected element(s) consists of the concatenation of all of the text from all of the child nodes of the selected element or elements, with each run of consecutive whitespace Unicode code points [code points with the White_Space property, such as U+0020 (SPACE), U+0009 (CHARACTER TABULATION), U+000A (LINE FEED), U+000C (FORM FEED), U+000D (CARRIAGE RETURN), U+00A0 (NON-BREAKING SPACE), and U+2029 (PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR)] compressed to a single U+0020 (SPACE). The metadata scheme needs to allow unambiguous selection.

section.title: IPR Statements
section.t: The IPR boilerplate for the document appears in a <div> element, which follows directly after the Abstract. The <div> element has an id attribute with value 'ipr' and a CSS class of the name of the relevant IPR ruleset. The only valid values for the IPR ruleset class are trust200902, noModificationTrust200902, and noDerivativesTrust200902 at this time. The contents of the <div> element are to be set correctly for the given ruleset, based on guidance from the IETF trust. For example:

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document contains no actions for IANA

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Since RFCs are sometimes exchanged outside the normal Web sandboxing mechanism (e.g., rsync to a mirror) then loaded from a local file, more care must be taken with the HTML than is ordinary on the web.
